DOC.HEAD: Settlement Near in Onassis Dispute Over Martha's Vineyard Lot
DOC.TEXT: Jacqueline Onassis' dispute with the Wampanoag Indians over a prime beach-front property that the Indians say contain the graves of a chief and his wife may soon be resolved, lawyers for both sides say. Wampanoag lore holds that Chief Moshup and his wife, Squant, are buried on the disputed Martha's Vineyard land. Moshup, according to the oral tradition, threw his children into the sea when he saw the white man approaching. Mrs. Onassis bought a 17 percent interest in the Gay Head beach property in 1980 from a Wampanoag family that has owned the property since the state surveyed and divided up Gay Head in 1870. A hearing expected to settle the matter of the 264-foot stretch of coastal property was set for Feb. 2, Onassis attorney Brian Hurley said Tuesday. ``There have been negotiations but we're not quite there yet,'' he said. The beach is held in undivided interest by more than 25 individuals, including Mrs. Onassis. But since she purchased her part of the beach, the widow of President Kennedy has fought the matter in court. Her private 380-acre retreat surrounds the beach. Paul Sulla, a Boston attorney and Gay Head resident representing the Indians, said a settlement was close. He declined to discuss the terms. The Wampanoag are descendants of the island's first settlers. Mrs. Onassis bought the acreage for her home in the mid-1970s and since then has brought a series of legal actions in an attempt to clear the title on the adjoining land. In turn, the Wampanoag sued Mrs. Onassis to retain access to the property.
